When I upgraded my home theater I went with a projector. Some of the new stuff out there is really good, requiring a special paint on your walls instead of a screen. Higher resolution than a high res TV, and about 5 times the life cycle, and fully scalable.
 
 For just a few dollars more than what a high def wide screen would have cost, I got the projector, the special paint for the wall (which looks just like bright white, but is not....I tried bright white first) and even a neat little trolley for the projector so it folds up into the ceiling when not in use.
 
 Fully viewable in direct sunlight (some of the old projection systems were not). 
 
 While certainly a different route, for my purposes it has proven exemplary.

 There are plenty of AV consultants out there. I could see if mine can help if you would like. He started a new job that has a non competition clause attached to employment, so he does not sideline anymore, but he might be able to do something.
 
 As far as the disapearing screen, not a problem, but it leaves you with a big, ugly enclosure on your wall. Personally, I prefer the paint on screen. A white wall is never really out of place, and while there is allegedly some image quality loss over a traditional screen, I can't see it. 
 
 Your top priority should probably be finding somebody who can recommend a projector and give you a proper focal length for it for the size you are after. I failed to do so when we were constructing our house, and ended up having to take out a wall and a ceiling to run cables. Very unpopular with the wife.
 
 you might also make allowances in the ceiling for speakers (walls, too). No need for ugly surface mounts. Most of the better speaker manufaturers now have good speakers available for in wall or in ceiling mount. A set of power/control wires terminating above windows to control your blinds is a good idea, since even if you do not put in electric blinds now, they can be added later if you wish, and you might start looking at lighting controls now. The ones I opted for just replace your original switch. There was a set made that I actually liked better, and allowed for better remote control, but they required a set of control wires, which would have required cutting into the wall that I had just had replaced. My wife would have killed me in my sleep.
 
 I know if I had to re-do my setup, the only thing I would really change is that I would have planned better from the start. It is good that you are taking these things into consideration as you go. Our original plan called for a standard wide screen high def with the standard controls. It was not until I went and visited my parents at their new house and saw the system my dad had put in (which is much better than mine....bigger picture and custom made theater style couch seating.....very cool) that I decided I wanted something a little different from the norm. 
 
 My wife is not properly appreciative of the system, but my nieces and nephews certainly are. When they come over for family events, the first thing to happen is generally the connection of the Xbox. They love the system for their games.
 
 In the end, I don't spend enough time using it to really enjoy it or give a long term opinion of it. It was fun to set up, though, cheaper than you might expect, and is a cool "guy toy", so I will give it full marks.

 Mine s 1450x1050, but I generally run it in 1024x768 mode. Of course. your picture cannot be better than the input. I like the high res (whcih obviously blows so called "high res" tv's out fo the water) for one other reason. if you are going to incorporate a PC into your entertainment system, you can use the projector as a monitor and it is actuallly useful, as opposed to most setups (even High res setups) where using the TV as a monitor makes for a terrible picture and illegible text.
 
 Using the projector as your monitor, though gives access to your MP3 collection. 
 
 One mroe thing, you migh look into on the fly adjustable picture size. The way mine is set, movies and such are shown full screen,. but if youa re using the MP3 player function it only shows as a 17" picture in the corner, and the picture is projected on a touchscreen (available on Ebay for about $35) so you have touchscreen controls for stereo MP3 functions. Probably not really necessary, but it can be a pain sorting through your MP3 collection, even with a good remote control setup (and do NOT skimp on the remote setup....it is the difference between a system that is easy and fun to use and one that is a pain in the butt to use).
